A riveting, powerful novel about a pilot living in a world filled with lossÃ¢â‚¬â€and what he is willing to risk to rediscover, against all odds, connection, love, and grace.

Hig survived the flu that killed everyone he knows. His wife is gone, his friends are dead, he lives in the hangar of a small abandoned airport with his dog, his only neighbor a gun-toting misanthrope. In his 1956 Cessna, Hig flies the perimeter of the airfield or sneaks off to the mountains to fish and to pretend that things are the way they used to be. But when a random transmission somehow beams through his radio, the voice ignites a hope deep inside him that a better lifeÃ¢â‚¬â€something like his old lifeÃ¢â‚¬â€exists beyond the airport. Risking everything, he flies past his point of no returnÃ¢â‚¬â€not enough fuel to get him homeÃ¢â‚¬â€following the trail of the static-broken voice on the radio. But what he encounters and what he must faceÃ¢â‚¬â€in the people he meets, and in himselfÃ¢â‚¬â€is both better and worse than anything he could have hoped for.

Narrated by a man who is part warrior and part dreamer, a hunter with a great shot and a heart that refuses to harden, The Dog Stars is both savagely funny and achingly sad, a breathtaking story about what it means to be human.
